description: {"blocks":[{"key":"9nji6","text":"For metabarcoding purpose, the first step involves the amplification by PCR of a given gene region (for example V3 or V5 region of 16S rRNA gene) or gene itself if its size does not exceed 600bp (the longest fragment size that can be sequenced by Illumina technology). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ej46n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"amof3","text":"The defined forward and reverse primers that are complementary upstream and downstream of the region of interest, needs to be designed with overhang adapters which will be used in a subsequent limited‐cycle amplification step, in order to add the dual‐index barcodes and Illumina flow cell adapters. To design illumina primers, it will be necessary to know the sequencing method, and therefore the adapters sequence. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9k2dn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ete12","text":"The following protocol explains the amplification of variable regions 4 and 5 of the 16S rRNA gene for prokaryote metabarcoding analyses from seawater samples for sequencing by the Get-PlaGE platform, Toulouse, France.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2c74i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qjuh","text":"The 515f-806r bacterial/archaeal primer pair, designed by Caporaso et al. (2011), was shown to be biased against some aquatic bacteria. The alternative primer set modified with additional degeneracy (Parada et al. (2015) and Apprill et al. (2015)) reduce the biais against important marine prokaryotes (such as the SAR11 clade, Crenarchaeota/Thaumarchaeota).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a748j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ggd4","text":"Primers 515F-Y (5'-GTGYCAGCMGCCGCGGTAA) and 926R-R (5'-CCGYCAATTYMTTTRAGTTT) yield more estimates of mock community abundances and produce longer amplicons.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3arh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"581os","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9iqhh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7rbg","text":"Quantify and quality-check the final DNA via NanoDrop or Qubit/PicoGreen Method. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aele0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9r00d","text":"The A280/260 ratios should be 1.8 or higher and once working with total community extracted DNAs, a concentration of at least 1 ng/μLis desirable to get consistent PCR results. Avoid secondary extractions or clean-ups for inhibitors, until PCRs have truly shown inhibition (example after trying the PCR by diluting the original DNA and/or adding BSA to the final PCR reaction)–many suboptimal DNAs will still work in PCR. A gel can be run to verify integrity of the extracted material, but it is generally unnecessary for PCR-only studies (Figure 1). Some protocols suggest the normalization of the DNA samples concentration prior to the PCR. In our experience, this is not always possible given the low concentration of some samples. The volume of sample added to the PCR can be settled in function of a range of concentrations instead of normalizing all the samples to the same concentration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":540,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"656g6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"epv6v","text":"Load in agarose gel 0.8%, 1μl DNA + loading buffer. {"blocks":[{"key":"cjq7b","text":"Below is a suggestion of protocol for bacterial 16S amplification from total genomic DNA. This protocol has been tested and used with success.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ov3l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f7lhd","text":"However, before starting the library preparation, few samples from the batch (es) to be analyzed should be selected and the PCR conditions should be tested. The tests can be performed by using the primers without the illumina “tail” which are less expensive since it can be order by normal purification method, like Se-POP. By using also these primers, it avoids excessive manipulation of the primers with the illumina tail and therefore the chances of contamination. Low number of cycles, pool multiple (i.e., triplicate) PCRs for each sample, high initial time of denaturation are fundamental practices for the PCR when targeting diversity studies and should be considered for all reactions, including the tests in order to reduce or avoid PCR bias caused by PCR selection and PCR drift.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5v35b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqrgs","text":"• PCR  selection includes all mechanisms which inherently favor the amplification of certain templates due to properties of the genes and/or of their flanking sequences of the target region. Potentially important contributors to PCR selection are preferential denaturation due to overall low GC content, higher binding efficiency of GC-rich permutations of degenerate primers, differential accessibility of rRNA genes within genomes, and correlation between amplification probabilities and gene copy numbers within genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":2,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5u0or","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqi8g","text":"• PCR drift is cause by stochastic variation in the early cycles of the reaction (when amplification still proceeds largely from the genomic templates), and its outcome should therefore not be reproducible in replicate PCR amplifications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":2,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"44og8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5q8mk","text":"More details about these biases can be found in the following references: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3albv","text":"-Aird, D. et al. Analyzing and minimizing PCR amplification bias in Illumina sequencing libraries. Genome Biol. 12, R18 (2011).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15taf","text":"-Wagner, A. et al.
